title: Micah Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Micah chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Micah Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Micah Chapter 6.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say to arise and contend before in Micah 6:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The mountains
questions.explanation: Micah 6:1 says, 'Arise, contend thou before the mountains, and let the hills hear thy voice.'

questions.question: According to Micah 6:2, with whom does the LORD have a controversy?
questions.correctAnswer: His people Israel
questions.explanation: Micah 6:2 states, 'For the LORD hath a controversy with his people, and he will plead with Israel.'

questions.question: In Micah 6:3, what does the LORD ask his people to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Testify against Him
questions.explanation: Micah 6:3 says, '...testify against me.'

questions.question: Who were the leaders sent before Israel as mentioned in Micah 6:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses, Aaron, and Miriam
questions.explanation: Micah 6:4 states, '...I sent before thee Moses, Aaron, and Miriam.'

questions.question: What event involving Balak and Balaam is recalled in Micah 6:5?
options: Balak consulted Balaam from Shittim unto Gilgal
Balaam cursed the people of Israel
Balaam led the Israelites out of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Balak consulted Balaam from Shittim unto Gilgal
questions.explanation: Micah 6:5 says, 'O my people, remember now what Balak king of Moab consulted, and what Balaam the son of Beor answered him from Shittim unto Gilgal.'

questions.question: According to Micah 6:6, with what does the speaker wonder if they should come before the LORD?
options: Burnt offerings with calves of a year old
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt offerings with calves of a year old
questions.explanation: Micah 6:6 asks, 'shall I come before him with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old?'

questions.question: What three things does the LORD require according to Micah 6:8?
options: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
To build altars, offer sacrifices, and keep festivals
To pray daily, fast often, and give alms
To sing praises, tell stories, and keep the law
questions.correctAnswer: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8 clearly states, 'He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the LORD require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?'

questions.question: True or False: Micah 6:7 suggests giving the firstborn for transgression as a way to please the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 6:7 asks, 'shall I give my firstborn for my transgression, the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?' indicating this is a question about what pleases the LORD.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:9, who shall see the name of the city?
questions.correctAnswer: The man of wisdom
questions.explanation: Micah 6:9 states, 'The LORD'S voice crieth unto the city, and the man of wisdom shall see thy name.'

questions.question: What is said about the treasures in the house of the wicked in Micah 6:10?
options: They are given to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: They are treasures of wickedness
questions.explanation: Micah 6:10 asks, 'Are there yet the treasures of wickedness in the house of the wicked?'

questions.question: True or False: Micah 6:11 says that the LORD will count the wicked balances as pure.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 6:11 questions, 'Shall I count them pure with the wicked balances, and with the bag of deceitful weights?' implying the balances are not pure.

questions.question: What are the rich men full of according to Micah 6:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence
questions.explanation: Micah 6:12 states, 'For the rich men thereof are full of violence.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Micah 6:14: 'Thou shalt eat, but not be _______'?
questions.correctAnswer: satisfied
questions.explanation: Micah 6:14 says, 'Thou shalt eat, but not be satisfied.'

questions.question: What will happen to the olives and sweet wine according to Micah 6:15?
options: Thou shalt tread the olives, but shalt not anoint thee with oil; and sweet wine, but shalt not drink wine.
Thou shalt harvest olives and drink sweet wine.
Thou shalt sell the olives and sweet wine for profit.
Thou shalt plant olives and make sweet wine.
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt tread the olives, but shalt not anoint thee with oil; and sweet wine, but shalt not drink wine.
questions.explanation: Micah 6:15 clearly describes this situation, indicating loss and frustration.

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 6:16, people walk in the counsels of Omri and Ahab.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 6:16 states, 'For the statutes of Omri are kept, and all the works of the house of Ahab, and ye walk in their counsels.'

medium.title: Micah Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Micah Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Micah 6:8 teach us about humility in our walk with God?
options: To walk humbly with God is required by the LORD
To seek riches and power above all
To rely on sacrifices alone for righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: To walk humbly with God is required by the LORD
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8 clearly states that the LORD requires us to walk humbly with Him, alongside doing justly and loving mercy. This teaches humility as an essential part of our relationship with God.

questions.question: A fellow believer asks what God requires instead of many sacrifices. Based on Micah 6, what would you share?
options: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
To offer thousands of rams and rivers of oil
To give their firstborn for transgressions
To follow the statutes of Omri and Ahab
questions.correctAnswer: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
questions.explanation: Micah 6:6-8 contrasts costly sacrifices with the true requirement of God: justice, mercy, and humility. This shows God values righteous living over ritual offerings.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:3-4, how does God remind His people of His faithfulness?
options: By recalling their deliverance from Egypt and the leaders He sent
questions.correctAnswer: By recalling their deliverance from Egypt and the leaders He sent
questions.explanation: Micah 6:3-4 reminds Israel how God delivered them from Egypt and sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam to lead them, demonstrating His faithfulness and care.

questions.question: What warning about honesty and integrity is given in Micah 6:10-11?
options: Using deceitful weights and abominable measures is condemned
It is acceptable to cheat if it benefits you
Wealth obtained by violence is blessed
questions.correctAnswer: Using deceitful weights and abominable measures is condemned
questions.explanation: Micah 6:10-11 condemns dishonest business practices like using false weights and measures, emphasizing the importance of integrity in daily life.

questions.question: How does Micah 6:12 describe the consequences of violence and deceit among the rich?
options: Their actions bring sickness and desolation due to sin
They will be exalted by God
questions.correctAnswer: Their actions bring sickness and desolation due to sin
questions.explanation: Micah 6:12-13 explains that violence and lies among the wealthy lead to God's judgment causing sickness and desolation because of their sins.

questions.question: What lesson about work and provision is taught in Micah 6:14-15?
options: Sowing without reaping and working without satisfaction will happen due to disobedience
Ignoring God leads to immediate wealth
One should not work at all
questions.correctAnswer: Sowing without reaping and working without satisfaction will happen due to disobedience
questions.explanation: Micah 6:14-15 teaches that disobedience leads to frustration in work and provision, illustrating consequences for unfaithfulness to God.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 6:16 praises following the statutes of Omri and the house of Ahab as righteous.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 6:16 condemns following the statutes of Omri and Ahab, associating them with desolation and reproach, not righteousness.

questions.question: How does Micah 6:1-2 demonstrate God's approach to addressing disputes with His people?
options: God calls all creation to witness and contends with His people openly
God hides His controversy and punishes silently
God pleads with other nations instead
questions.correctAnswer: God calls all creation to witness and contends with His people openly
questions.explanation: Micah 6:1-2 depicts God summoning the mountains and foundations of the earth as witnesses to His dispute with Israel, showing His desire for open accountability.

questions.question: A believer asks about the value of sacrifices. According to Micah 6:6-7, what is the biblical perspective?
options: Sacrifices alone cannot please God without righteous living
Thousands of rams will earn God's favor
Giving firstborn children is required for forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifices alone cannot please God without righteous living
questions.explanation: Micah 6:6-7 shows that expensive sacrifices and offerings are insufficient if not accompanied by obedience, justice, and mercy.

questions.question: What does Micah 6:5 teach about remembering God's past acts for encouragement?
options: Remembering God's deliverance and righteousness strengthens faith
Forgetting history is best for spiritual growth
Only present actions matter to God
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering God's deliverance and righteousness strengthens faith
questions.explanation: Micah 6:5 encourages recalling God's protection against Balak and Balaam, highlighting His righteousness and faithfulness as a foundation for trust.

questions.question: How does Micah 6:9 instruct the wise to respond to God's voice?
options: To hear the rod and who has appointed it as discipline
To ignore God's voice and continue sinning
To reject correction and pridefully resist
questions.correctAnswer: To hear the rod and who has appointed it as discipline
questions.explanation: Micah 6:9 calls the wise to recognize God's voice and accept His appointed discipline, teaching humility and responsiveness.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 6:13 warns that sin will bring sickness and desolation as a form of correction.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 6:13 states God will smite and make desolate because of sins, affirming that sin invites divine correction and consequences.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Micah 6:8 says the LORD requires us to do justly, to love mercy, and to walk _____ with our God.
questions.correctAnswer: humbly
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8 specifically commands walking humbly with God, emphasizing humility as a key requirement for faithful living.

questions.question: What practical application about stewardship does Micah 6:10-11 convey?
options: Honest measures and weights are vital to pleasing God
Using deceitful scales is acceptable if profitable
questions.correctAnswer: Honest measures and weights are vital to pleasing God
questions.explanation: Micah 6:10-11 criticizes wicked treasures and deceitful weights, teaching that integrity in stewardship is essential.

questions.question: How does Micah 6:16 connect leadership influence with consequences for the people?
options: Following corrupt leaders' statutes leads to desolation and reproach
Leaders have no effect on the people's fate
The people prosper despite wicked leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Following corrupt leaders' statutes leads to desolation and reproach
questions.explanation: Micah 6:16 warns that following the ways of leaders like Omri and Ahab results in desolation and bearing reproach, underscoring the impact of leadership on the community.

hard.title: Micah Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Micah Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Micah 6:8, what three actions does the LORD require of man?
options: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
To offer sacrifices, keep the law, and pray daily
To fast, give alms, and repent sincerely
To build altars, sing praises, and honor the priests
questions.correctAnswer: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8 explicitly states that the LORD requires man to do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God, emphasizing ethical and humble living rather than ritual sacrifice.

questions.question: Which historical figures does God remind Israel of in Micah 6:4 as part of His redemptive acts?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses, Aaron, and Miriam
questions.explanation: Micah 6:4 recounts how God brought Israel out of Egypt and sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam before them as leaders and deliverers, reminding them of His past salvation.

questions.question: What is the nature of the 'controversy' mentioned in Micah 6:2 that the LORD has with His people?
options: It is a legal dispute or lawsuit between God and Israel
It is a battle between Israel and their enemies
It is a covenant renewal ceremony
It is a prophetic vision about the future
questions.correctAnswer: It is a legal dispute or lawsuit between God and Israel
questions.explanation: Micah 6:2 uses courtroom imagery where God pleads His case against Israel, indicating a covenant lawsuit or 'rib' (Hebrew: rib) between the LORD and His people.

questions.question: In Micah 6:5, the prophet recalls the consultation between Balak and Balaam. What is the purpose of this reference?
options: To remind Israel of God's righteousness and protection
To warn Israel about foreign alliances
To highlight the sin of Balaam
To encourage Israel to worship Moabite gods
questions.correctAnswer: To remind Israel of God's righteousness and protection
questions.explanation: Micah 6:5 recalls Balak's attempt to curse Israel through Balaam, but God's righteousness prevailed, demonstrating His protection over Israel.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Micah ask in Micah 6:6 to challenge improper worship practices?
options: Shall I come before the LORD with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old?
Can I build a temple greater than Solomon's?
Is fasting alone enough to please God?
Should I offer silver and gold for forgiveness?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall I come before the LORD with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old?
questions.explanation: Micah 6:6 uses this question to highlight Israel's misguided emphasis on ritual sacrifice instead of genuine obedience.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:7, which extreme act is questioned as a means to atone for sin?
options: Giving my firstborn for my transgression
Building a high altar on the mountain
Dedicating all my wealth to the temple
Offering thousands of lambs at the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: Giving my firstborn for my transgression
questions.explanation: Micah 6:7 asks if the LORD would be pleased with giving the firstborn as a sin offering, pointing to the absurdity of trying to earn favor through costly sacrifices.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Micah 6:1-2 when God calls upon the mountains and hills to hear His voice?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: Micah 6:1-2 attributes human qualities to mountains and hills by inviting them to 'hear' and 'contend,' a clear example of personification.

questions.question: Which theme prominent in Micah 6 is also emphasized in the New Testament book of James?
options: The necessity of righteous actions and mercy over mere ritual
The prophecy of the Messiah's birth
questions.correctAnswer: The necessity of righteous actions and mercy over mere ritual
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8’s call to do justly and love mercy parallels James 2:14-26’s emphasis on faith being demonstrated by works and mercy.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 6:12 states that the inhabitants' tongues are deceitful in their mouths.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 6:12 explicitly states that the inhabitants have spoken lies and their tongues are deceitful, emphasizing moral corruption.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Micah 6:14, "Thou shalt eat, but not be ___; and thy casting down shall be in the midst of thee."
questions.correctAnswer: satisfied
questions.explanation: Micah 6:14 uses this phrase to describe the judgment on Israel where they will eat but not be satisfied, signifying frustration and judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of the reference to 'the statutes of Omri' and 'the house of Ahab' in Micah 6:16?
options: They symbolize the continued idolatry and evil practices that led to Israel's downfall
They represent a golden age of Israel's history
They are examples of righteous kings to emulate
They indicate foreign alliances that protected Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize the continued idolatry and evil practices that led to Israel's downfall
questions.explanation: Micah 6:16 condemns the people for following the evil practices of Omri and Ahab, kings associated with idolatry and injustice.

questions.question: What does Micah 6:3 suggest about God's relationship with Israel?
options: God is questioning how He has wronged His people, showing a covenantal bond
God is indifferent to Israel's actions
God is unaware of Israel’s sins
God plans to abandon Israel without cause
questions.correctAnswer: God is questioning how He has wronged His people, showing a covenantal bond
questions.explanation: In Micah 6:3, God asks Israel what He has done to them, implying He desires their testimony and highlighting the covenant relationship.

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'wicked balances' and 'deceitful weights' in Micah 6:11 contribute to the chapter's message?
options: It symbolizes corruption and injustice in commerce and society
It portrays the importance of accurate measurements in worship
It warns against foreign economic alliances
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes corruption and injustice in commerce and society
questions.explanation: Micah 6:11 uses these images to highlight dishonest economic practices as part of the people's sin.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:10, what is described as being in the house of the wicked?
options: Treasures of wickedness and scant measure that is abominable
questions.correctAnswer: Treasures of wickedness and scant measure that is abominable
questions.explanation: Micah 6:10 condemns the wicked for hoarding ill-gotten treasures and using dishonest scales, indicating moral decay.

questions.question: What does the prophetic language in Micah 6:13-15 foreshadow about Israel's future?
options: Judgment through famine, desolation, and failed harvests
The building of a new temple
The rise of a new king from David's line
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment through famine, desolation, and failed harvests
questions.explanation: Micah 6:13-15 uses vivid judgment imagery of sickness, desolation, unsatisfying food, and failed crops to foreshadow coming punishment.

theological.title: Micah Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Micah Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:4, which leaders did God send before Israel when He redeemed them from Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses, Aaron, and Miriam
questions.explanation: Micah 6:4 states that God sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam before Israel when He brought them out of Egypt. This is consistent with Exodus 15:20-21 and Numbers 12:1-15, where these leaders played key roles in Israel's deliverance.

questions.question: What three requirements does the LORD specify in Micah 6:8 as what He requires from His people?
options: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
To offer sacrifices, keep the law, and build altars
To fast, pray, and give alms
To obey the prophets, keep the Sabbath, and tithe
questions.correctAnswer: To do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8 clearly outlines God's ethical demands: justice, mercy, and humility with God. This aligns with Jesus' teaching in Matthew 23:23, Hosea 6:6, and Proverbs 21:3 emphasizing mercy and justice over ritual sacrifice.

questions.question: In Micah 6:6-7, which offerings are questioned as insufficient to please the LORD?
options: Burnt offerings, calves of a year old, thousands of rams, rivers of oil
Grain offerings, incense, silver, and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt offerings, calves of a year old, thousands of rams, rivers of oil
questions.explanation: Micah 6:6-7 questions whether burnt offerings, young calves, thousands of rams, or rivers of oil can satisfy God. This critiques reliance on ritual sacrifices apart from true repentance, echoing Isaiah 1:11-17 and Amos 5:21-24.

questions.question: Who does Micah 6:5 reference as a witness to the righteousness of the LORD?
options: Balak king of Moab and Balaam son of Beor
Pharaoh king of Egypt and Jannes the sorcerer
Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and Daniel
Saul king of Israel and Samuel the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Balak king of Moab and Balaam son of Beor
questions.explanation: Micah 6:5 refers to Balak and Balaam to remind Israel of God's righteous acts in protecting them. This is consistent with Numbers 22-24 where God thwarted Balaam's curses, showing His sovereign righteousness.

questions.question: What is the nature of God's controversy with His people as described in Micah 6:2?
options: A legal dispute over covenant unfaithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: A legal dispute over covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Micah 6:2 depicts God's controversy as a legal case against Israel for covenant breach, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:1-43 and Isaiah 1:18-20 where God pleads with His rebellious people.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:12, what sins characterize the rich men and inhabitants of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence, lies, and deceitful tongues
questions.explanation: Micah 6:12 condemns rich men for violence and the people for lying and deceit, echoing Proverbs 6:16-19 and Jeremiah 7:9-10 where such behavior is sinful and opposes God's justice.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Micah 6:14: 'Thou shalt sow, but thou shalt not _____.'
questions.correctAnswer: reap
questions.explanation: Micah 6:15 states 'Thou shalt sow, but thou shalt not reap,' illustrating the judgment of fruitless labor due to Israel's sin, paralleling Hosea 10:13 and Jeremiah 12:13.

questions.question: Micah 6:1 calls on which natural features to hear the LORD's words?
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains and hills
questions.explanation: Micah 6:1 calls mountains and hills to witness God's case against Israel, a common biblical motif found in Deuteronomy 32:1 and Habakkuk 3:3 where the earth testifies to God's justice.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare in Micah 6:13 for Israel's sins?
options: He will smite and make them desolate
He will forgive and restore them
He will bless them with prosperity
He will send prophets to guide them
questions.correctAnswer: He will smite and make them desolate
questions.explanation: Micah 6:13 warns of divine judgment—smiting and desolation due to sin, consistent with the prophetic warnings in Isaiah 5:25 and Jeremiah 25:8-11 about consequences of rebellion.

questions.question: According to Micah 6:16, whose statutes and works do the people continue to follow, resulting in desolation?
questions.correctAnswer: Omri and Ahab
questions.explanation: Micah 6:16 states that Israel follows the statutes of Omri and works of Ahab, kings associated with idolatry and evil, leading to judgment, paralleling 1 Kings 16:29-33 and 2 Kings 17:7-23.

questions.question: In Micah 6:3, God asks, 'O my people, what have I done unto thee?' What theological principle is emphasized here?
questions.correctAnswer: God's faithfulness despite human unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Micah 6:3 highlights God's faithfulness and calls Israel to acknowledge their failure, reflecting the covenant relationship seen in Exodus 20:2-6 and Psalm 89:30-33 where God remains faithful.

questions.question: What does Micah 6:9 suggest about those who have wisdom in relation to the LORD's voice?
options: They will heed the rod and its appointment
They will rebel against God's law
They will seek human counsel instead
questions.correctAnswer: They will heed the rod and its appointment
questions.explanation: Micah 6:9 states that the man of wisdom will hear the rod and who appointed it, indicating acceptance of God's discipline, consistent with Proverbs 3:11-12 and Hebrews 12:5-11 about divine chastening.

questions.question: Micah 6:10-11 criticizes the use of wicked measures. What does this symbolize about Israel's moral state?
options: Dishonesty and injustice in commerce and life
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonesty and injustice in commerce and life
questions.explanation: Micah 6:10-11 condemns deceitful weights and measures, symbolic of Israel's pervasive dishonesty, paralleling Proverbs 11:1 and Leviticus 19:35-36 which demand honest scales.

questions.question: Micah 6:14 says, 'Thou shalt eat, but not be satisfied.' What theological theme is expressed here?
options: The futility of sin and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The futility of sin and judgment
questions.explanation: Micah 6:14 describes the emptiness of sinful pursuits under judgment, echoing Ecclesiastes 6:7 and Isaiah 55:2 which teach that apart from God, satisfaction is impossible.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'walk humbly with thy God' in Micah 6:8 for Christian theology?
options: It emphasizes submission and dependence on God
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes submission and dependence on God
questions.explanation: Micah 6:8's call to walk humbly with God highlights the believer's attitude of submission and reliance on divine grace, resonating with James 4:6, Philippians 2:5-8, and 1 Peter 5:6.
